summary: Pattern interrupts reset viewer attention by breaking predictable visual/audio patterns, creating dopamine feedback loops that maintain engagement. Human brains pattern-match as survival mechanism; interrupting patterns forces re-engagement.

core_principles.description: When videos become predictable (e.g., static talking head for minutes), brain 'tunes out' anticipating no new threat or information. Pattern interrupts force re-engagement.
Pattern interrupt acts as 'jolt' forcing brain to re-process visual context. Can be subtle (camera angle change) or overt (sound effect, graphic).
Strategic deployment of interrupts creates chain of re-hooks every 30-60 seconds, preventing boredom onset and maintaining continuous engagement.
Visual state should change every 3-10 seconds to reset attention clock. Changes include: cuts, zooms, overlays, B-roll, sound effects.
Visual interrupts most effective when paired with auditory triggers. Sound alerts brain to visual change before eyes register it.
Interrupts must be intentional and contextually relevant. Random changes without purpose feel chaotic; purposeful interrupts enhance narrative.

techniques.name: Camera Angle Change
techniques.description: Switch between wide shot and close-up to emphasize specific points. Creates visual variety without requiring new footage.
implementation: Cut to close-up when speaker leans in for intimate or important content
Cut to wide shot for relaxation or topic change
Can be achieved through editing or actual camera moves

techniques.name: Full-Screen Graphics
techniques.description: Hard reset of visual palette using full-screen solid color background with text, meme, or graphic. Creates strong visual break.
implementation: Design full-screen graphic with key message or visual
Use for emphasis, comedy, or section breaks
examples: Display key statistic in bold text

techniques.name: B-Roll Insert
techniques.description: Cutaway to illustrative footage while speaker continues audio. Visualizes spoken concept, reduces cognitive load.
implementation: Sync B-roll with spoken word (Say-See synchronization)
Color grade to match A-roll for cohesion
examples: Speaker mentions 'writing' → pen on paper B-roll

techniques.name: Zoom Cut (Punch-In)
techniques.description: Rapid digital zoom on emphatic beats or punchlines. Turns static shot into intentional emphasis through scale change.
implementation: Can be instant jump or smooth zoom
techniques.timing: On specific emphasis points, punchlines, or dramatic reveals
examples: Shocking statistic → zoom on number text

techniques.name: Sound Effect Sync
techniques.description: Every visual transition or text appearance accompanied by SFX. Creates tactile feedback, glues audio-visual experience.
implementation: Collect sound library (whoosh, pop, click, thud)
Match intensity to visual change type
techniques.timing: Every visual change needs corresponding SFX

techniques.name: Text Overlays with Kinetic Typography
techniques.description: Animated text that moves, scales, and evolves in sync with spoken word. Reinforces message through dual coding (reading + hearing).
implementation: Animate text to match speech timing
Position to avoid UI elements (safe zones)
techniques.timing: On key phrases, important points, or emphasis moments
examples: Speaker says '50% retention' → text animates in
Lists items → text appears with each item
pros_cons: Captures attention even with audio off
Design skill needed for professional look

techniques.name: Silence as Pattern Interrupt
techniques.description: Sudden cut to absolute silence in video filled with music/SFX creates loudest possible interrupt. Draws intense focus.
implementation: Cut all audio to silence at critical moment
techniques.timing: For sarcasm, serious emphasis, or punchline delivery
examples: Comedy punchline → audio drop creates space
Contrast example → music drop for emphasis
pros_cons: Draws intense focus to next element

techniques.name: Progress Bar or Completion Visual
techniques.description: Visual progress indicator showing video completion percentage. Leverages human 'completion bias' to encourage finishing.
examples: Bar at bottom fills as video progresses
pros_cons: Can be distracting if poorly designed

techniques.name: Meta-Commentary Break
techniques.description: Speaker breaks fourth wall to address editing process or video creation itself. Creates authenticity and engagement.
examples: 'Editor, zoom in on my face right now'
'This is the part where I mess up'

visual_change_types.description: Text or image appears over video
